awd_titl_txt: CRII: CPS: Hierarchical Control for Constrained Multi-timescale Energy Management
awd_abstract_narration:
Modern control systems, small and large, attempt to optimize resources based on information from more and different kinds of sensors, sensing modalities, environments, and circumstances.   This is especially the case for commercial and defense aircraft, vehicles, and ships, that optimize for fuel efficiency, performance, and safety. This research project develops a general control methodology for maximizing overall performance and efficiency, even when operating close to the physical limits of the system, all while ensuring safety and meeting overall objectives.
 
This research project develops a novel "set-based approach" to construct effective hierarchical model predictive control (MPC) with provable guarantees for cyber-physical systems (CPS), where coordination among controllers provides guaranteed satisfaction of actuator and state constraints.  The research of this project describes how CPS system constraints can be used to construct specific set-based coordination mechanisms for each controller within the hierarchy that provide provable closed-loop behavior for the entire system, how the underlying topology and dynamic timescales of the system is leveraged to develop system-specific hierarchical control architectures that minimize uncertainty and maximize performance, and how hierarchical control can be used for energy management and, e.g., provide greater capability, efficiency, and reliability for electrified vehicle systems.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The goal of this CRII project was to develop a fundamental understanding of model-based hierarchical control synthesis, analysis, and performance to enable provable control behavior for highly constrained multi-timescale Cyber-Physical Systems (CPS). Hierarchical control is widely used in industry to decompose control decisions for complex systems both vertically, among multiple levels of controllers operating at different timescales, and horizontally among individual systems, subsystems, and components. However, with most practical hierarchical control formulations, the closed-loop system cannot be readily analyzed to established guaranteed system operations, such as the ability to satisfy both actuator and state constraints, which are needed to ensure safe system operation.

To overcome these challenges, the intellectual merit of this project includes new set-based hierarchical control formulations, based on Model Predictive Control (MPC), where the use of sets as the primary coordination mechanisms between controllers in the hierarchy creates the ability to analyze closed-loop system behavior. These novel formulations resulted in hierarchical MPC controllers with guaranteed constraint satisfaction and performance. Zonotope and constrained zonotope set representations were an enabling tool that allowed set-based coordination mechanisms to be computed extremely quickly for online computations in real-time and for set operations and relationships to be included directly in the MPC optimization problem as linear constraints. This significantly improved the capabilities and performance of these hierarchical controller by allowing decisions and computations that typically need to be done offline due to their high computational cost to be done online to make real-time decisions in response to changing operating conditions.

The broader impacts of this work include closing the gap between academic and industrial controller formulations, where set-based techniques can be used to guide practical, high-performance, control formulations in industry where guaranteed safe system operation is required. Additionally, this project resulted in educational opportunities for two PhD students, one REU student, and several other undergraduate students. Research results were disseminated through 3 journal publications, 4 conference proceedings, and 1 PhD dissertation along with 3 journal publications currently under review and 1 additional PhD dissertation in the near future. The work in constrained zonotope set representations has resulted in an open-source MATLAB-based toolbox that provides a wide-variety of set operations and calculations applicable to many different engineering applications. The results of this project have also led to close ongoing collaborations with industry and colleagues at and outside the University of Texas at Dallas.
